turns.content: Can you suggest some books for learning photography techniques and composition?

1. Understanding Exposure: How to Shoot Great Photographs with a Film or Digital Camera by Bryan Peterson
2. The Photographer's Eye: Composition and Design for Better Digital Photos by Michael Freeman
3. The Art of Photography: An Approach to Personal Expression by Bruce Barnbaum
4. Creative Black and White: Digital Photography Tips and Techniques by Harold Davis
5. Understanding Composition: The Complete Guide to Creative Photography by Steve Mulligan
6. Mastering Composition: Techniques and Principles to Dramatically Improve Your Painting and Photography by Ian Roberts
7. The Complete Photographer by Tom Ang
8. Light and Lens: Photography in the Digital Age by Robert Hirsch
9. The Photographer's Mind: Creative Thinking for Better Digital Photos by Michael Freeman
10. The Camera: The Ansel Adams Photography Series 1 by Ansel Adams.
Can you recommend any photography podcasts or YouTube channels for me to follow as well?

Sure, here are some photography podcasts and YouTube channels you can follow:

Podcasts:
1. The Candid Frame - interviews with photographers 
2. This Week in Photo - a weekly photography news and industry discussion 
3. The Digital Story - tips and techniques for improving your photography 
4. The Art of Photography - a podcast of photography and visual storytelling 
5. Photography Tips From the Top Floor - topics include technique, gear, and creativity 
6. Improve Photography - tips and techniques for all levels of photographers 

YouTube channels:
1. Mango Street - a channel with tutorials and photo challenges 
2. DigitalRev TV - reviews and gear discussions in a humorous style 
3. Tony & Chelsea Northrup - tutorials, gear reviews, and discussions 
4. Peter McKinnon - tutorials, gear reviews, and vlogs 
5. Fstoppers - a channel featuring tutorials and behind-the-scenes content 
6. Jared Polin (FroKnowsPhoto) - tutorials, gear reviews, and photography news 
7. Ted Forbes (The Art of Photography) - discussions on photography and visual art 
8. PiXimperfect - tutorials on photo editing and retouching.

I can't believe how much I've learned about photography since we last talked! The resources you suggested were incredible. I feel like my photos have improved so much already. Do you have any suggestions for taking great portraits? I want to start photographing people more but am not sure where to start.

That's great to hear! I'm glad the resources have been helpful. Here are a few tips for taking great portraits:

1. Get to know your subject: Spend some time talking with your subject and getting to know them to establish a rapport. This will make them more comfortable and it will show in the photos.

2. Choose the right location: The location should complement the subject's personality or create the right mood. Look for interesting backgrounds, lighting, or textures that can add depth and interest to the photo.

3. Use lighting to your advantage: Lighting plays a key role in portrait photography. Use natural light or artificial light sources like a softbox, reflector, or speedlight to highlight your subject's best features and create interesting shadows.

4. Consider composition: Composition is important in any photograph, but especially in portraits. Use the rule of thirds, leading lines, or framing techniques to create a visually pleasing composition.

5. Experiment with different angles: Don't be afraid to experiment with different angles or perspectives to create a unique portrait. Shoot from above, below, or from unconventional angles to add interest to the photo.

6. Poses and expressions: Experiment with different poses and expressions to find the right one that captures your subject's personality. Always make sure the subject's body language and facial expressions look natural.

Remember that taking great portraits takes practice and patience, so don’t be afraid to experiment and take lots of shots!

Wow, these tips are great! I never really thought about getting to know my subject beforehand or experimenting with different angles. I'm excited to give portrait photography a try and see how my skills improve. Do you have any advice on how to edit portraits to make them look even better?

Yes! Here are some tips for editing portraits:

1. Start with basic adjustments: Before getting into more complex editing, make sure to adjust the basics like exposure, contrast, highlights, and shadows to make sure the photo has a good foundation.

2. Focus on the eyes: The eyes are the most important element in any portrait, so make sure they are sharp, clear, and bright. Use the tool of your choice to enhance the eyes and make them stand out.

3. Soften the skin: Softening the skin can help create a more polished look, but be careful not to overdo it. Use a brush or tool to smooth out any blemishes or skin imperfections, while still maintaining a natural-looking texture.

4. Adjust the colors: Adjusting the color of the portrait can help create a more appealing look or a certain mood. You can try adjusting the temperature, tint, or saturation to enhance the colors in the photo.

5. Use dodge and burn selectively: Dodging and burning can help balance the highlights and shadows in the photo to create a more balanced look. Use it selectively to highlight certain features or areas of the face.

Remember that editing is a very subjective part of the process, so it's important to use your own taste and style when editing portraits. Experiment with different techniques and find a style that works for you and your subject.
